column2: A network of power plants, substations, transformers, transmission and distribution lines, and sensors that carries electricity sometimes hundreds of miles to be distributed to our communities, homes, schools and offices
column3: The plot of the latitude and longitude of U.S. cities with the strongest governments
column4: A device used in gyms for increasing strength and muscle mass
column7: The network of power plants (all sources of generation), devices and lines that generates and distributes electricity across the country to be used by consumers is known as a power grid.

column1: The four main segments of the grid are . . .
column5: Phase I, Phase II, Phase III & Phase IV
column7: Electricity is generated at a power plant, transmitted at high voltages sometimes across many miles, distributed to homes and businesses and finally used.

column1: Who launched Pearl Street Station, the first commercial power plant, in lower Manhattan in 1882?
column7: The offices of the New York Times were one of Edison's first electricity customers.

column1: Does the electric grid deliver Alternating Current (AC) or Direct Current (DC)?
column7: Alternating Current (AC), which reverses direction a certain number of times per second, can be converted to different voltages relatively easily using a transformer. While electricity is predominantly AC, especially on the distribution side, there are some transmission lines in North America that are high-voltage Direct Current (DC) lines. In addition, a number of technologies such as PVs, electric vehicles, LEDs and computers are all DC.

column1: The power grid in the contiguous U.S. is actually made up of three independent power grids. What are they called?
column7: The two major interconnections are the Eastern & Western Interconnections. The third is the Texas Interconnected system, which covers most of Texas.

column1: What is the number one cause of power outages in the U.S.?
column3: Squirrels, birds & other animals chewing on wires
column7: Not only is severe weather the number one cause of power outages, but that number is expected to rise as climate change increases the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events. Preparing for the challenges posed by climate change requires investment in 21st century technology that will increase the resiliency and reliability of the grid.

column1: The nation's power grid is currently undergoing a major transformation to become smarter and more reliable. Which of these is NOT a new technology being used on the grid?
column7: While the grid is getting more and more technologically advanced, we haven't quite gone "back to the future."

column2: A mailbox-size device that monitors the health of the grid at intervals and degrees of granularity not previously possible
column3: A light saber from Star Wars
column4: The part of a cellphone that makes it automatically sync to the correct time zone
column5: The scientific name for a power outlet
column7: The enhanced visibility into grid conditions provided by synchrophasors helps grid operators identify and respond to deteriorating or abnormal conditions more quickly.

column1: When an outage occurs, who do you call?
column7: While a distribution electrician or utility line worker at your utility or muni or co-op builds, repairs and maintains the electric grid, outages should be reported directly to your local electricity provider.

column2: A reduction or restriction of electrical power in a certain area
column3: When the power goes out, but the sun's up, so you can see
column5: A power outage that only affects a small area
column7: Brown outs sometimes occur when there is a heavy load on the grid. New technologies that improve reliability are helping to prevent brown outs and blackouts.

column1: Who is involved in making sure the grid stays up and running?
column7: The electrical grid is a complicated network that relies on private and public partners working together to make sure the power keeps flowing.
